QuantumSure Documentation

Get started with our API and integration guides. Explore our comprehensive resources to implement quantum-resistant cryptography in your systems.

  • API Reference
  • Integration Guide
  • Best Security Practices
  • QuantumSure Encryption at a Glance
API Reference
Create Key

Creates a new API Key and Public Key for your use.
URI: https://quantumsure.onrender.com/api/quantumsure/create
Expected Parameters: none
Output: secret_phrase (string), public_key (string)
Example:

try{
const res = await axios.post(URI, {
data: null,
});
console.log(res);
}
catch (err){
console.log(err);
}

Delete Key

Deletes the API Key and corresponding Public Key.
URI: https://quantumsure.onrender.com/api/quantumsure/delete
Expected Parameters: api_key (string), secret_phrase (string)
Example:

const data = {
api_key: "yourkey",
secret_phrase: "yourphrase",
};
try{
const res = await axios.post(URI, {
data: data,
});
console.log(res);
}
catch (err){
console.log(err);
}

Encrypt Data

Encrypts the target string with Quantum Resistant Cryptographic Algorithms.
URI: https://quantumsure.onrender.com/api/quantumsure/encrypt
Expected Headers: api_key (string), public_key (string)
Expected Parameters: normal_text (string)
Output: encrypted_text (string)
Example:

const data = {
normal_text: "let us test some sample text to encrypt",
};
const headers = {
'api_key': "yourapikey",
'public_key': "yourpublickey"
};
try{
const res = await axios.post(URI, {
data: data,
}, {
headers: headers
});
console.log(res);
}
catch (err){
console.log(err);
}

Decrypt Data

Decrypts the target encrypted text string back to the text you provided in the Encrypt request.
URI: https://quantumsure.onrender.com/api/quantumsure/decrypt
Expected Headers: api_key (string)
Expected Parameters: encrypted_text (string)
Output: normal_text (string)
Example:

const data = {
encrypted_text: "yourencryptedtext"
};
const headers = {
'api_key': "yourapikey",
}
try{
const res = await axios.post(URI, {
data: data
},
{
headers: headers
});
console.log(res);
}
catch (err){
console.log(err);
}

Integration Guide
Creating a Key

Currently we are providing a free sample in plans. Please click on 'generate my keys'. Safely store the secret phrase, api key and the public key, since we do NOT keep them on our end (to make it impossible for even us to read your data). If you lose these, your data can NEVER be recovered.

Deleting a Key

Go to plans and click on 'delete my keys' after inputting your secret phrase and api key. Note that this is irreversible.

Encrypting and Decrypting Data

In your javascript project, in the .env file of your root directory, keep the public key (PUBLIC_KEY), API Key (API_KEY), and secret phrase (SECRET) as environmental variables, and then call the functions as shown in the API Reference section. Access the returned values with res.data.encrypted_text or res.data.normal_text.

Best Security Practices

Please DO NOT share your secret_phrase, api_key, or public_key with anyone, because that would allow them to delete your account, and they will also be able to generate a lot of training data by using your keys to generate encrypted text for normal text data.

QuantumSure Encryption at a Glance

QuantumSure using multiple encryption algorithms, and decoy mechanics to ensure the safety of your data, and its resistance to hacking and unauthorized access, even when pitted against Quantum Computers. The technology involves Kyber1024, Fernet-like, and decoy based encryption.

Kyber 1024: Kyber is an IND-CCA2-secure key encapsulation mechanism (KEM)[1], whose security is based on the hardness of solving the learning-with-errors (LWE) problem over module lattices. Kyber is one of the finalists in the NIST post-quantum cryptography project. The submission lists three different parameter sets aiming at different security levels. Specifically, Kyber-512 aims at security roughly equivalent to AES-128, Kyber-768 aims at security roughly equivalent to AES-192, and Kyber-1024 aims at security roughly equivalent to AES-256.
The design of the Kyber encryption is rooted in the seminal LWE-based encryption scheme of Regev. Since Regev's original work, the practical efficiency of LWE encryption schemes has been improved by observing that the secret in LWE can come from the same distribution as the noise and also noticing that "LWE-like" schemes can be built by using a square (rather than a rectangular) matrix as the public key. Another improvement was applying an idea originally used in the NTRU cryptosystem to define the Ring-LWE and Module-LWE problems that used polynomial rings rather than integers. The CCA-secure KEM Kyber is built on top of a CPA-secure cryptosystem that is based on the hardness of Module-LWE.

Fernet-like Encryption: Fernet guarantees that a message encrypted using it cannot be manipulated or read without the key. Fernet is an implementation of symmetric (also known as “secret key”) authenticated cryptography. Fernet also has support for implementing key rotation via MultiFernet. [2]
It uses the following processes internally:
-AES in CBC mode with a 128-bit key for encryption; using PKCS7 padding.
-HMAC using SHA256 for authentication.
-Initialization vectors are generated using random number generators.
Since the original implementation of Fernet is in Python, QuantumSure calls its method "Fernet-like Encryption" because it is built in a different language (javascript), and uses additional safety checks to make it even more robust.

Decoy-based Encryption: This is a unique implementation, specially created in-house by the QuantumSure cryptographers. It involves generating a key, and using it as an operand in a formula, instead of directly giving it to the client for end usage. This ensures that the public keys cannot be bulk generated and tried with different testing datasets to "guess" the private key. The exact algorithm and implementation is black boxed to ensure that malicious parties can't break past this additional layer of security.
